Sure, here is an example of how noise and texture can be used in visual art to evoke emotions:

Imagine a painting of a stormy ocean, with waves crashing against the shore. The artist could use a variety of techniques to create a sense of noise and texture in the painting. For example, they could use loose, expressive brushstrokes to create the appearance of turbulent water, with thick, textured paint to give the waves a sense of power and movement. They could also use more chaotic, abstract forms to represent the spray and foam of the waves, adding to the overall sense of noise and chaos in the painting. By using these techniques, the artist could create a sense of uncertainty and unease in the viewer, evoking feelings of fear or awe in response to the power of the stormy ocean.
